climbs.name: Math
climbs.fa: Robert Alexander and Eric Fogel, October 1986

content.description: This route is significantly easier than the 5.10B rating in the guidebook, and is not sustained at all.  The crux is a short wide chimney.  The rest is mostly wide crack, but quite easy.
content.protection: standard rack, but be sure to bring some wider gear (to 4 inches)
content.location: This is the crack system about 20 feet right of Aftermath.

content.description:
Located just to the right of Houdini Arete/The Great Escape with a horizontal pine tree at the base.

Bombay flare leads to a hand crack.  Not a bomb, and worth doing if in the area.  Good experience for the odd wide flares with hand cracks in the back.
This route surmounts the crack on the left side of the Baby Roof. Descend by downclimbing the gully on the climber's right of the route.
content.protection: Thin pro up to 3 inches and some flaky rock.
content.location: Just to the right of Baby Roof.

climbs.name: Geometry
climbs.fa: Robert Alexander, Eric Fogel, Nick Beer, and Ruth Galler, Oct. 1986

content.description:
Just left of Aftermath lies a low roof with a finger crack.  A block juts out just below the roof.After the roof, easier climbing leads to the top.

This route is basically boulder problem, as the difficulty eases significantly about 15' off the ground.
content.protection: Normal rack, fingers for the route, hand/hand+ for the anchor.

content.description: This climb heads up the face 15 feet right of Baby Roof. Descend by downclimbing the gully on the climber's right of the route.
content.protection: None on route. Good gear anchor at the top.

content.description: This is a short, fun hand crack.
content.location: This hand crack is to the right of Made In The Shade, on the far right side of the formation.

climbs.name: Foreign Legion
climbs.fa: Pete Charkin, Alan Roberts, Bruce Howatt and Shane Swain 1985

content.description: Immediately left of the Houdini Arete/Great Escape is this thin crack.  Rated .10d in the Vogel guide, it is easier than it looks.  Not worth travelling for, but a worthy tick.
content.protection: Small nuts and cams for the route.  Hand and hand+ for the anchor.

content.description: It takes some thought...  Good climb.

This is the face between Aftermath and Math.

Climb a silver slab past several grey knobs (liebacking a bit on the right-hand edge) then follow a flake/thin crack that diagonals up and left. Make a delicate step-up onto a big knob, then crimp up a short, steeper section on edges, finishing up a juggy flake/crack.

Very good rock quality.

climbs.name: Baby Roof
climbs.fa: Alan Roberts, Pete Charkin & Bruce Howatt, 1985

content.description: Really fun roof climb.  The roof is probably more like a 5.6.  The crack above the roof is about 5.4.  The pro is excellent.  I would recommend this for a new trad leader.
content.protection: small cams to #2 and nuts.  Gear anchor.

content.description:
Climb the arete right of Baby Face passing over a small roof near the bottom. One star out of five.

So named for the ubiquitous yellow signs plastered in the back window of cars.

More info about Baby On Board signs

climbs.name: Baby Face
climbs.fa: John Thackray and Todd Swain, March 1987

content.description: This is a slab route on good rock.  The moves are interesting, and there is a long runout on the crux.
content.protection: two bolts and a light rack
content.location: This is on a slab just left and uphill from Aftermath.

climbs.name: Arms Are For Hugging
climbs.fa: Todd Battey, Dave Stahl, Tom Burke, Rob Stahl, Feb. 1987

content.description: At the begining of the Elsmere area, near ground level there is a boulder with a sloping arete ( looks a bit like an elephant's trunk ).  The route steps out onto the blunt arete and squeezes its way up from there.  The technical crux moves are very well protected.  As for beta, the name says it all.
content.protection: Four bolts to a 2 bolts anchor.  One of the anchors has a loose nut, a few turns with a wrench would do it some good.

climbs.name: Aftermath
climbs.fa: FA: Pete Charkin, Alan Roberts, Bruce Howatt 1985

content.description: It is 30' right of Baby Roof, just left of an orange dihedral (Houdini Arete), and about 100 yards up from the desert floor. A great hand crack at the bottom with fun traversing with some exposure at the top. This is a great climb to practice hand crack technique, especially the first 25 feet.
content.protection: Standard rack up to Camalot 3.5.  Depending on your crack technique, you may want doubles of the hand size pieces for the bottom hand crack.

climbs.name: Able Was I Ere I Saw Ellesmere
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel, Darrel Hensel, and Alan Roberts, January 1986

content.description: A crux wide hands start leads to hand jamming and then a corner with finger jams.  The rock quality is good.
content.location: This is near the north end of Ellesmere Island.  It is above the Arms Are For Hugging formation, and below the formation with Made In The Shade and Fright Night.  The approach is a bit tricky.
